documents.commentText: I am not and do not believe I will ever be a kratom user. However, I'm fully aware of the constant pain and agony associated with injury and arthritis and know how debilitating it can be. The answer in the United States has always been opiates. I do not need to educate anyone who has ever been on opiates or has known someone who takes opiates about the danger in these pills. We know they're dangerous. We know they kill. We know they are addictive and were designed specifically to be addictive. That is not to take away from the people who manage their opiate addiction well or have successfully gotten off opiates. Some people are successful in that regard and will continue to be successful. But we can't keep pretending this flawed system is the only solution to chronic, long-term pain. Kratom is as natural as any other substance used to alleviate pain and has virtually none of the drawbacks. Could it have some serious drawbacks? Yes, of course. We have not yet studied it in depth enough and don't have nearly enough data to know for certain. What we do know for certain is it's incredible ability to alleviate pain, elevate mood and well being (having taken ibuprofen for many years, some mood elevation is simply the fact that you are not constantly worried about pain when it is eliminated; some of that could just be a natural response to the lack of chronic pain), and it does not exhibit the addictive/toxic properties associated with opiates. When a drug such as Vicodin binds to an opiate receptor, the process of addiction has in essence already begun. Those receptors gobble up the drug like a shark smelling blood in the water. What makes Kratom unique is that when it binds to an opiate receptor, it binds in a way that is not nearly as extreme. Your body literally metabolizes it differently and in a way that makes it, possibly, non-addictive. Again, we do not have enough information to make either all positive or all negative remarks on it. But the fact that it exhibits the same healing properties as some of our most powerful drugs in a way that is totally different than what we've been accustomed to should be reason enough to at least investigate the merit of this drug. Millions of Americans suffer from chronic pain. I am not discrediting the effectiveness of opiates. I am simply suggesting that, based on evidence, there is enough reason to consider kratom for scientific study and open-minded investigation. We cannot deny that it has already had a powerfully positive influence on the people who have gone out of their way to use it. Should we decide to ban even as evidence of it's potential superiority to older methods continues to mount, I truly believe we are depriving millions of Americans a powerful tool that could assist them in their day to day lives.

The devastation that I witness first hand on a daily basis  that opiates, pills, and heroin, and Suboxone cause across this once great nation can hardly be substantiated in this 5000 characters.

Clean up my act when ever my amazing wife would catch on to my behavior, Just to sneak around buying pills & lying to everyone about it.  But they all knew. Or the financial burden to each state for the costs of rehabs and treatment facilities.  The numbers would be mind blowing I have a feeling. These are not widely used substances, and the small amount of the population that does use them are generally not adversely affected by them. I posit, also, that the small population that does consume these substances is more widely educated than the general population in regard to their effects. To whom it may concern, 

I have suffered for the last decade from multiple surgeries to a sensitive area of my body and I experience post operative pain on a regular basis. Additionally, I have a form of arthritis that causes moderate pain in my muscles and joints that I have endured since I was a teenager. These issues impact my quality of life, and interfere with my ability to perform well in some working scenarios. I have found some relief from traditional opioid pain medication, but it is catch 22 that over time also impacts my quality of life, and my ability to perform well in some working scenarios.

When I discovered mitragyna speciosa and began to use it, I found that it was able to help mitigate the pain as well as increase my mood, and I am not experiencing some of the inevitable side effects that came from traditional pain medication. After researching online about the "less is more" hypothesis, the "plateau effect", and the built in limitation that nausea ultimately imposes; I perceived that when compared, natural mitragyna versus refined opiate drugs was far safer to use and had fewer negatives attached to use. In my opinion, relegating this plant to any level of the controlled substance schedule is premature and unwarranted.

Consider the cost of the so called "war on drugs" that has been ravaging families and ruining lives for decades in this country. Consider the prison industrial complex and the cost of keeping so many non violent people locked up for exercising the right to ingest naturally occurring substances that cause little if any harm. Consider the racial and economic disparities that are prevalent in the enforcement of existing laws. Consider the social ills of a black market, the violence of street gangs, and the proliferation of international cartels that come prohibition. 

I appeal to you of intelligence and conscience to reconsider the drastic effects that scheduling this plant would have. The history of prohibition is clear: Twice we have tried as a society to criminalize nonviolent consumption (alcohol and cannabis), twice it has caused unnecessary harms far in excess of the paltry side effects encountered in the normal use of those substances. In comparison, perhaps you would consider that education and harm reduction have had more success in slowing the consumption of legal products such as tobacco, alcohol and refined sugar; all of which have been shown to have far reaching consequences on health.

I appreciate that you have read, and taken the time to understand the benefits and concerns that I have outlined here. Let's not repeat the same mistakes that were made a hundred years ago. Let's avoid the trauma of the decades of a war that cannot be won. Let's let people have the dignity and freedom to choose for ourselves. 

Thanks!

Im 65 yrs old.  Married 42 yrs. to the same man.  I dont drink or smoke.  I do drink Kratom tea.  For that I may soon become a felon.  This tea restored my life.  It is one of the best things I have ever done for my mental and physical health and the DEA is considering making it a schedule one drug along with heroin?

A few years ago I damaged my spine.   Within seconds Id altered the course of my life forever.  Due to the severity of the pain I was given oxycodone while doctors exhausted every possible method of repairing the damage.  Nothing worked and surgery became unavoidable.   

Time ticked on.  Oxycodone became less effective & Oxycontin was added to my pain regimen to prolong relief.

There was no negligence by doctors involved with my treatment.   This was simply a difficult situation with no easy answer.  Their choices, like mine, were limited.

Improvement from surgery was minimal.  We continued to explore options while I continued to take opiate pain meds to survive.

It doesnt take long to become addicted to opiates.   Tolerance is a serious problem.  The longer you take them the more you need.  Eventually you find yourself on an opiate hamster wheel chasing doses and finding little relief.   

The solution becomes the problem.  

I opted to come off  the meds.  I dont know how familiar you are with our current drug rehabilitation programs but it can take weeks or months for a bed to open up.  For a street addict this may be the difference between life and death.   Here again, options are too limited.   

For months after Id stopped opiates, I was in agony.   Scans revealed several additional and permanent spinal problems.  Unable to live a remotely normal life I resorted to excessive amounts of over counter meds.  Terrified this would eventually damage my kidneys and liver, I began searching for more natural methods of pain control.

I found Kratom while researching herbal supplements and pain control.   But the real beauty of Kratom is, its not just an herbal supplement.  Its a community. Numerous sites are populated with people just like me.   They were able to tell me what to buy and how much tea to begin with.   These folks check on me daily.   We share exercises, healthy recipes, and challenge each other to keep doing better.   

This past year Ive had the pleasure of watching young heroin addicts come into our groups looking for help. Watching these pups, ages 22-34,  beat addiction with the help of a few senior citizens and a cup of tea is beautifully magical. 

These kids are now attending college, pursuing careers, and buying homes. Heroin and prescription opiate addictions are an epidemic in this country.   This tea and these people are fighting to stop that.  We should be thanking them.  Not condemning them.

If at some point a company chooses to use those patents pending to create an RX form of Kratom theres no reason both cant exist comfortably.   Its my belief this would be the best of both worlds.  We need to work together to stop the opiate epidemic.  In the brief time I spent as a prescription opiate addict I learned quickly this is an extremely demeaning illness. Please dont take this herbal supplement and the community born from it away from those of us who desperately need them to function.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

I oppose the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances. From my own experience, I do not think kratom -- a plant consumed safely by thousands of people every year -- should be on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. I own a local shop in Chicago where we sell Kratom products. I found myself in the business after hearing about kratom from my best friend whose brother died from a heroine overdose. I want to help those in need of an alternative, natural pain managing supplement. Since opening the shop, I have met so many wonderful individuals using Kratom for a variety of reasons. Most are looking for a way to manage their pain, whatever that pain may be. My customers are firefighters, contractors, artists, engineers, teachers, chefs, CEOs, moms, dads, adult children and grandparents. I do not want to see their lives thrown into chaos if they are forced to turn to additive pain managers or forced to live with their pain. I have seen kratom help so many individuals. I hope the DEA will carefully consider what will happen to the thousands of individuals using kratom if a ban goes in to effect. I do not want to see any of my friends/customers forced to use additive (legal prescription or illegal) drugs to manage their pain, especially when kratom has helped so many of them. I have seen individuals use kratom on a as need basis and I do not know of anyone who is addicted to kratom. 

Just today, I saw a study conducted by Walter C. Prozialeck, PhD and published in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. He concludes "based on all of the evidence, it is clear that kratom and its mitragynine constituents are not opioids and that they should not be classified as such." He writes that "after evaluating the literature, I can reach no other conclusion than, in pure herbal form, when taken at moderate doses of less than 10 to 15 g, pure leaf kratom appears to be relatively benign in the vast majority of users." I hope his study will be taken into consideration. It can be found here: jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524. I have also heard that scheduling of kratom would prevent future research, which I think would be a huge disservice to entire human population. I hope more studies can be conducted to show how the primary alkaloids in kratom may be beneficial without causing respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

I urge the DEA to halt the ban until further, in-depth studies can be performed. I believe that those who use kratom are responsible and educated. I know there is an opioid epidemic in this country- my best friend's brother died in their bathroom from a heroine overdose. However, taking away a natural supplement that could replace an opioid as pain management would only continue that epidemic. I wish my friend's brother would have tried kratom before his passing. I believe it may have saved him.

Kratom is not a drug and does not deserve to be regulated as one.  It is a dietary supplement, no different from other common herbs such as valerian root, skullcap, passion flower, etc., that millions of people around the world have used to benefit their lives.  If the scheduling of kratom proceeds, the American People will suffer a significant negative impact on their lives, finding themselves with no access to an herbal remedy that many find to be an effective antidiarrheal, analgesic, treatment for opiate addiction, alternative to caffeine, and sleep aid, among it's many other uses.  Also, academic research into this potentially valuable plant will be unable to continue.  It's safety profile is clear cut - it has been used for thousands of years by Asian civilizations with no significant long-term detrimental impacts.  Indeed, this has been partially studied: "Our findings suggest that chronic kratom administration does not significantly impair social functioning of users in a natural context in Malaysia." (1)  Regarding any instances of supposed harm that has occurred involving kratom - I strongly urge you to remember that ANY substance, even water, can become hazardous when used improperly, and this is just as true of virtually all legal dietary supplements.  The risk to public health is spectacularly minimal, as is the scope, duration, and significance of any supposed "abuse".  This is verified by a CDC report which confirms that in the five year period between 2010-2015, an incredibly minute grand total of 660 poison center calls were reported to involve kratom, of which an astounding 92.6% of cases of exposure were reported to involve "minimal signs or symptoms, which resolved rapidly with no residual disability" or were "non-life threatening, with no residual disability..." (2)  It is obvious from these figures that no substance with a significant actual or relative potential for abuse could possibly have that few number of calls while also being relatively obtainable to the degree that kratom is.  In fact, to this date, no deaths can be ascribed solely to the usage of kratom, as verified by a 2016 review which states "there is no solid evidence that kratom was the sole contributor to an individual's death". (3)  In comparison, a drug that is actually deserving of Schedule 1 status, Heroin, has resulted in over 10,500 deaths in 2014 alone, while also being far more difficult to obtain relative to kratom. (4)  In short, the facts demonstrate that kratom most certainly does not meet the criteria for scheduling (either temporary or permanent).  If you proceed with the scheduling of kratom (and/or banning it through the scheduling of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine), you will be reaching beyond your legal authority and gravely violating the trust placed in you by the American People.  I implore you to not unfairly take away our rights.

My name is Gregory Zambelli and I am a sixth year PharmD student. From the perspective of a pharmacist, I am extremely concerned that this ban will have far reaching negative consequences for many patients across the country. Kratom is an herb ,that has been used safely for hundreds of years and helps tens of thousands of people nationwide. It is not a new synthetic drug, which is what the emergency scheduling provision in the CSA was designed to address. Many people who suffer from chronic pain, anxiety, drug cravings and chronic fatigue use kratom to support their overall health and wellbeing. On top of that, anecdotal evidence suggests that many patients managed to completely cut opioids out of their lives because of this plant. The active ingredient in the plant, Mitragynine , does have some mild partial  effects on the mu opioid receptor but does not cause any respiratory depression. The main mechanism of action does not involve traditional mu agonism, rather from a collection of alkaloids that effect a large array of receptors in the brain including opioid antagonists. The main alkaloids in the plant also do not activate the beta-arrestin pathways, which are proteins in the brain that cause respiratory depression. Due to the lack of full agonism, kratom is unlikely to produce an effect comparable to other full agonist opioids. There have been NO deaths directly related to kratom. The 15 deaths your administration referred to all involved kratom with a large mixture of pharmaceutical drugs. The 660 poison control calls cited by your agency was not put into context.Legal herbs that have widespread use, such as Echinacea , Gingko Bilboa , St. John Worts, have all received has thousands of calls. Also the vast majority of poison control calls were ranked as mild or moderate . In 2014 an estimated 458 people died from acute liver failure from misusing Tylenol, should the DEA ban that as well?  

At this time there a lot of barriers in the healthcare system to receive treatment for their health conditions, and a large section of patients do not tolerate prescription drugs well. While there is no medical use for kratom based on evidence-based medicine, we should not stop a person who wants to ingest a plant that improves their well-being and avoid more dangerous drugs. While self-treating conditions should not be encouraged, healthcare professionals should be open-minded about the use of the herb and still attempt to forge a therapeutic alliance with patients.  Many conventional opioids and replacement therapy (buprenonorphine,methadone) have many side effects that can potentially make them hard to tolerate. Traditional opioid replacement therapy can cause serious adverse effects, such as nausea, sexual side effects, sedation and many more. This plant has a substantially better safety profile than methadone,suboxone, prescription painkillers,SSRIs,benzos based on the mortality data we have on all the substances. More long-term studies on kratoms effect on health need to be done, but nothing in the literature suggests this drug is an imminent public health threat. While clinicians should not be advocating its use, it is not appropriate for the government to turn all kratom users into potential felons. This ban will cut a lifeline for many people, and could result in a lot of death if patients choose to resume illicit drug use or start back on riskier prescription drugs after the ban.This measure will only worsen the current heroin/fentanyl epidemic that is killing thousands of citizens.I agree it is disgusting that some convenience stores/headshops are marketing this as a "legal high", and I support a retail ban/age restrictions so teenagers do not have access to the herb. There are many sensible restrictions that can be done; such as age limits (21) , have the FDA standardize and regulate vendors and a total retail ban of the herb a supplement, and banning alkaloid extracts. If the DEA/FDA main concern is it being marketed for consumption at smoke shops/gas stations, then encourage congress to create legislation to ban this avenue of sale. Companies should absolutely not get away with selling the herb with medical/recreational claims, and the FDA should penalize businesses that attempt to do this. The raw leaf though should be available for adult consumers who want a natural remedy to improve their wellness/quality of life. 

This is a complicated issue and I urge you to consider reconsider your intention to ban the plant. Dealing with the people who return to opioids after the ban will cost the government potentially millions of dollars in law enforcement costs. Also the loss of productivity in the people who utilize it will negatively effect the economy.

Dear Sir:

I am a 35 year old lawyer who lives and works in Boston, Massachusetts.  I have safely consumed kratom for some time, and it has helped me to manage chronic pain resulting from a back injury without resorting to addictive pharmaceuticals.  For the foregoing reasons, I would request that you NOT schedule kratom as a controlled substance, either on an emergency basis or otherwise.  

First of all, there is a complete absence of any evidence whatsoever that kratom poses a danger to the public.  In support of the fact that no public health emergency exists as a result of the consumption of kratom, I would point to a recent survey of medical professionals finding that there have been no widespread concerns about the use of kratom within the medical community.  That results of that survey may be found at: http://216.30.191.148/112957_AKA_ER_Trauma_Professionals_Online_Survey_Report.pdf.  Secondly, and with regards to the DEA's contention that kratom is an opioid equivalent to heroin or other opium derivatives, I would point you towards the recent publication of an article in the Journal of the American Osteopathic Association, entitled "Update on the Pharmacology and Legal Status of Kratom," explaining in some detail why kratom should not be considered an opioid, and further should not be considered a threat to public health.  Rather, the DEA should consider kratom an essential tool in the fight against the opioid crisis.  There can be no doubt that the opioid crisis must be addressed, and kratom provides a relatively low risk tool to fight addiction-- and one that appears far less dangerous and habit forming than traditional forms of replacement therapy such as methadone and suboxone.  It would foolish in the extreme to ban the use of such a helpful plant-based alternative at a time like this. Finally, I would urge you to take a careful look at the 8 factor analysis submitted to the DEA by Pinney Associates on November 30, 2016, concluding that there is no basis to schedule kratom at any level, and no reason to believe that kratom poses any danger to the public.  

I would also ask you to disregard the biased and self-serving comments made by Dr. Daniel Fabricant on behalf of the "Natural Products Association," claiming that kratom is supposedly more dangerous than the supplements touted by the industry he works on behalf of.  Not only is that claim unsupported-- as the above referenced materials demonstrate-- but the very supplements he so passionately defends have in fact been responsible for an estimated 23,000 emergency room visits, according to a July 2016 study by Consumer Reports, which may be accessed at http://abcnews.go.com/Health/consumer-reports-highlights-dietary-supplement-dangers/story?id=40919592.  The minimal number of any reported instances of adverse reactions to kratom of course pale in comparison to such a number, as you are no doubt aware. I urge you to disregard his baseless and plainly self-serving commentary, and to carefully consider the comments and materials submitted to you by thousands of American consumers whose lives have been improved by the use of this plant.  The productive, healthy lives we are leading are the best evidence you could have of the safety and efficacy of this plant.  Thank you for your consideration.

I'd like to voice my opposition to the intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. To date, research has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

I was once prescribed 240 (TWO HUNDRED FORTY) oxycodone per month by Kaiser Permanente.  Their plan was to keep me on this medication and increasingly stronger medications (with combinations of other weaker opiates) until I turned 65 years old when they would do a full knee replacement surgery.  Needless to say, taking massive amounts of dangerous and highly addictive pain medication was a horrible action plan and I let them know that it was a horrible plan.

There are no known incidents of harm/overdose from taking *just* kratom by itself (any evidence of death or overdose has always been in combination with multiple other substances that all interacted dangerously--and fatally--with each other). I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without kratom and I do not know how I will continue to work in my new career of diagnostic ultrasound without either taking kratom or taking absurd amounts of dangerous prescription pain medication.

Outlawing this plant will only serve to criminalize more of our people, expand the inexcusable conditions of mass incarceration in our nation, destroy more families, exacerbate opiate use  prevent valuable research and both fuel and support the expansion of the unprecedented numbers of cartel thugs and violent street gangs that have flourished and grown a thousand fold over the past 45 years - because of drug prohibition.

Stephen Downing

documents.commentText:
I am writing in favor of delaying or withdrawing the proposed Schedule I classification for Mitragyna speciosa and its active constituent chemicals. 

As a neurologist practicing in Santa Monica, California, and who treats patients with opiate dependence, I am challenged by the inadequate treatments available for helping patients reduce and eliminate the use of opiate pain medications.  As you know, the prescription opiate epidemic is truly a public health emergency, and there is substantial anecdotal evidence that Mitragyna speciosa can be a safe and effective treatment for patients tapering and stopping chronic opiate pain medications.  

Moreover, my review of the literature regarding adverse effects indicates that patients who have suffered overdoses were taking Mitragyna speciosa in addition to illicit drugs that are known to have serious and deadly complications.   For patients consuming Mitragyna speciosa in standard doses or under a supervised treatment plan, there is no definitive evidence that this medication is in fact toxic. 

For these above reasons, I believe that Mitragyna speciosa warrants more formal investigation.  I have a pending Institutional Review Board application to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Mitragyna speciosa for patients undergoing opiate pain medication tapers.  This will be the first step to potentially applying for a new drug application through the Food and Drug Administration.

It is my belief that Mitragyna speciosa very likely has the potential to become a safe and effective standard treatment for patients suffering opiate dependence and stopping their use opiate medications and may very well prove to be life-saving in a large number of cases.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern, 

My name is Rene Breen. I am 27 years old and a resident of Lockport NY. I have never tried Kratom and as  I have no reason to. But Kratom has saved my life. Please allow me to explain. 

When I was 22 I married my high school sweetheart. Andrew is the most incredibly selfless, hardworking, loving man I have ever had the privilege to know. We have built a life together by working hard and honestly. We have both gone to school, worked long hours and struggled to make ends meet. But through it all, we have been determined to succeed. My husband works in a skilled trade which requires manual labor. At only 26, he has injured his back, knees and hip so badly that some mornings he can hardly get out of bed. 

I don't know if you've ever had to watch someone you love struggle to get out of bed in the morning, but let me tell you... It's awful. I will never forget the day he looked at me with tears in his eyes and said "If it's this bad now, how will I even walk in a few years?" My heart was broken for him. I was watching the strong man I loved fall to pieces day by day. Doctor after doctor suggested medicines with side effects that ranged from stomach problems, high blood pressure and the danger for addiction. He was told his only option was surgery. That was when the fear hit a new height. We'd watched people we went to high school with die from opiate use after an injury. We'd seen people lose everything over chronic pain and drug abuse. We were terrified this would be a real possibility for us. 

A holistic approach had to exist. We researched everything from acupuncture and chiropractors to teas and ice/heat therapies. Nothing seemed to help. Finally in our research we discovered Kratom. To say I was skeptical would be an understatement. I spent MONTHS researching it. I found absolutely nothing to suggest that Kratom was dangerous. I gave my husband the green light and prayed I wouldn't regret it.

Personally, I have never taken a recreational drug ever in my life. My experience with drugs was limited to antibiotics, allergy medicines and the prenatal vitamins I take. I do not condone recreational drug use. I have seen far too many young lives lost to the opioid epidemic. I have seen marriages end, children end up parent less and worse. I would never give my husband the green light to get high for his own enjoyment. 

Though my skepticism ran deep, the results have been better than I can articulate.  My husband is himself again. He still feels pain sometimes but the Kratom has given him his quality of life back. He can go for walks with me. He can get comfortable enough to sleep at night. He does not have to worry about withdrawals or getting addicted. He has stopped taking it several times through the years without any side effects with the exception of a headace, much like caffeine causes. He is never "out of it" or high in any capacity. He's able to do his job and help around the house. Without laying on the drama, just understand that Kratom has lived up to the hype. It has saved our lives. 

I understand that it is important to regulate substrates like this. I welcome you to. Dosages, content, all should be examined. But this is not a drug of criminals. This is a natural pain reliever. It's as beneficial as a cup of green tea. The only deaths associated with Kratom have included other substances in conjunction with Kratom. Please, begin the clinical trials  and research this drug deserves. It can save lives. It already has. 

To sum this up, I want to express the fear we feel right now. Kratom is our lifeline. If the scheduling of Kratom happens, I am afraid of how we will have to manage my husband's pain. He's only 26 years old - far too young for invasive surgeries or harsh drugs to help him cope. Please, please, please.... I beg you. Do not take this natural pain reliever away.

Since then, I've spent a great deal of time educating myself about kratom and have become increasingly concerned that an opportunity for valuable research might be squandered in a myopic, poorly-justified governmental effort to repress the use of a substance with some opiate-like characteristics.

Notice that I say "some" and opiate-"like". Over 20 bio-active alkaloids have been detected in kratom. Except for mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, those alkaloids may be present in some strains and not others, some in young leaves and not older leaves. Thus the physical effects of kratom use can vary with the strain, age and drying method of the leaves, as well as the quantity used. Some varieties can be sedating, some anxiolytic, some stimulating. Some strains are both anxiolytic and stimulating, which I don't believe can be said for opiates. Imagine a painkiller that's both highly effective for severe chronic pain AND non-narcotic (in the sense that narcotics tend to be stupefying). Imagine an opiate-LIKE painkiller that doesn't suppress breathing. 

The variety of human-beneficial effects produced by kratom deserves to be exhaustively studied, and it has not been. Putting this plant substance on a narcotics schedule, particularly Schedule 1, will greatly inhibit further study in the United States. Meanwhile, highly addictive substances with no medical utility, like tobacco and alcohol, are not treated like drugs at all. The irony is inescapable. 

I have little hope that people's comments here, whether from grandmothers, veterans, medical professionals, the chronically ill or those recovering from opiate addiction, will have any effect on the DEA's decision-making. Rather, I must hope that pro-kratom lobbyists and legal teams will be able to sway decision-makers to take a sane course, toward scientific inquiry and away from knee-jerk reactionism. 

Some regulation of kratom would be appropriate, including establishing age limits and requirements for safety inspections. But designating this multi-purpose, medically-useful tree leaf as a Schedule 1 narcotic like heroin or Ecstasy would be a case of fear and bias overtaking reason. I'd hate to see this in my country. I'd hate to see so many grandmothers, veterans and professionals, like those commenting here, turned into felons overnight, and with such weak justification.

documents.commentText:
The American Herbalists Guild (AHG) is a non-profit, educational, member-based association of herbal practitioners founded to represent the goals and voices of herbalists specializing in the medicinal use of plants. We currently represent over 2000 practitioners, educators, students, and others who utilize herbalism is a safe, effective, and therapeutic fashion. The AHGs primary goal is to promote a high level of professionalism and education in the study and practice of therapeutic herbalism, whether based on modern biomedical, traditional, or other approaches.

The AHG would like to publicly as well as directly to the DEA state our opposition to the classification of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as Schedule I substances according to the Controlled Substances Act (CSA)  a regulatory move that would effectively ban the plant kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) which contains these constituents.

The AHG considers such a step to be unjustified.  As noted by AHPA and others, there is no precedent for the DEA to use its emergency authority in this manner for a naturally occurring substance such as a plant.  As documented elsewhere (Yearsley - Herbalgram, McGuffin and Young - AHPA) the serious adverse health effects including deaths that have been in some cases potentially attributed to kratom are more likely due to adulteration and/or concomitant use of hazardous and toxic substances.

Schedule I classification would also be highly counterproductive in terms of gaining additional scientific knowledge about kratom and its potential uses, as well any potential safety concerns, in that such a legal classification would overly restrict further scientific research into not only its safety but also its therapeutic value.

The AHG urges the DEA to permanently set aside the potential classification of kratom as a Schedule I drug as inappropriate, given all we know of its uses and safety based on both science and tradition.  We believe that it is vital that plants with a long tradition of therapeutic use such as kratom remain accessible to the public.

In this era when we are witnessing many health and sociological epidemics, now is not the time to ban this plant that could be an invaluable asset in the fight against addiction, crime, and overall anxiety. 

I have used kratom for five years, and it has brought nothing but benefits to my life. Those benefits include pain relief, reduction of anxiety and stress, and an increase in motivation and overall life satisfaction. Since I began using kratom, I have developed into a productive member of society, a person who seeks to make the world around all of us a better place. Though this development is not fully due to kratom, I can say with full confidence that it played a large role in the process. Without kratom, I would be in more pain, more stressed, less happy, and less motivated. If kratom exists and can aid these things in reality, why should anyone be stripped of its help? Why would anyone wish that a persons right to want to live happily, without pain, be restricted? 

I have used roughly the same dose, between 3-6 grams, for the entirety of the last five years, and have never sought to increase the dose or chase a high. This is because kratom does not get you high, and it has a ceiling effect. What this means is that smaller doses often work better than larger ones, motivating people to remain at low doses in their own experiences. Practically this creates the opposite of drug-seeking effects, and contributes to the well being of users by offering an antidote to the habits of constant consumption found in our culture. If this aspect of dosage were to be discovered in some other supplement, or even in a traditional medicine, surely it would be hailed by the scientific community as miraculous. We should not ignore this quality in kratom.

I live with pain that stems from a disease called Legg-Calve Perthes disease, which I was diagnosed with at the age of 12. Currently I have arthritis developing in the disease-affected hip, which limits which activities I can do, and causes a virtually constant sense of pain that radiates throughout my leg. Because of my young age, doctors will not prescribe me painkillers, nor do I want them to  I have seen how dangerous that road could be. On the other hand, OTC painkillers fail to work, even on a minor level. 

Before kratom, I lived with the thought that there were no options for me, and that I would simply have to tough it out. Seeing doctors look down on me for simply trying to get relief made me feel that somehow, the pain was my fault. It was a twisted system that left me sad and confused, but I grew closer with each day to breaking down and accepting it.

By bringing kratom into my life, I found relief, and once again felt like a normal, pain-free person. To a person who has lived with constant pain for decades, the sudden and natural absence of pain caused by kratom is miraculous. 

The relief I get from kratom is mild, gentle, and yet effective. It is not something that can be used as an escape route  I am still well aware of my life and the problems in it. Contrary to pharmaceutical opiates, kratom gives me the deep-rooted motivation to get things done, to go out and achieve for myself the things that will improve my life. 

Throughout history, we have seen time and again that policies of prohibition do not work. 
We are not seeing sufficient results with these policies, yet we keep pursuing them, and people are taking notice. In a recent MTV Opioid Awareness special, President Obama himself maintained that our focus should shift from incarceration towards treatment and help for addicts. This is an amazingly relevant validation of the idea that we cannot enforce and imprison our way out of the opioid epidemic. We have been trying that for the last century, and we have only ended up where we are today. 

By banning kratom, we will be taking our first steps down a path that will only intensify all the problems I have mentioned. It will remove a safe, natural tool from the hands of thousands of responsible adults, whose suffering in life will increase needlessly. The laws will put more non-violent offenders in prison, people who could not even remotely be considered criminals  people like the doctors, teachers, and nurses who contribute much to the functioning of our society. 

In conclusion, I strongly oppose a scheduling of kratom, of any kind, and instead support other measures, such as regulation similar to how current dietary supplements are being handled. This, coupled with an age limit to keep it out of the hands of minors, is a common-sense way to move forward while allowing citizens the personal freedom they want and deserve. With these things easily within reach, there is no good reason to ban this plant.

documents.commentText:
I'm a PhD student in the area of Physical Chemistry, and I'm familiar with the biochemistry of kratom in particular out of an interest in natural medicine. I've used kratom periodically for nearly 8 years with so far no tangible negative effects. I've been through significant depressions for by various causes before in my life and kratom has allowed me to continue functioning normally at work as a chemical simulation scientist.

I've encountered a lot of uninformed news media over the last decade calling kratom everything from a hallucinogen to "like heroin", all of which are false to the point of absurdity. The alkaloids the DEA wants to ban are active at the opioid receptors but completely lack any type of "high". They also seem to totally lack respiratory depression, the primary cause of death by opioid overdose. Reading through the scientific literature on kratom reveals that mitragynine alkaloids have no structure in common with any known opioids. Mitragynine and 7-hydroxy mitragynine possess several properties in common with alkaloids which are known to prevent addictive behavior (G-protein coupled receptor activity, mixed agonist/antagonist activities at the mu receptor, etc.). The currently known facts of mitragynine and derivatives along with more than a decade of notable consumption by the public with no deaths or serious injuries clearly attributable to kratom means that there is no threat to the public. Attempting to ban kratom in spite of the facts will likely be perceived by its 3-5 million consumers (and likely many more) as having ulterior motives.

Banning kratom in the US will result in a black market (since Canada and Mexico will not be scheduling kratom). In addition, without a harm reduction approach like regulation as a dietary supplement there will be no monitoring of kratom quality, a direct cause of deaths due to kratom which had been adulterated by hard opioids.

There is also the fact that kratom has been helpful to millions of people with insufficient health insurance coverage. Kratom empowers millions to take control of their own health when they may be unable or unwilling to get treatment for medical conditions due to cost or for social reasons (and medical mistakes are now one of the most likely causes of premature death in the US). Even more, it would be a genuine disservice to the people to ban what many addicts consider to be a godsend, allowing them to get clean from opiates without the need to come out to the world as addicts, possibly destroying their future family and employment prospects.

We are now in the midst of an epidemic of opioid addiction among Americans. There are likely many causes, not the least of which is the need to work harder and longer for less compensation. Kratom is almost certainly the best potential solution to this epidemic. Taking it away from the public's control will cause massive inflation in cost for those who do manage to get a prescription for it. It's safety profile alone should be sufficient to warrant sales of kratom as a dietary supplement as it is in Canada. But it has the potential to save the lives of millions of addicts who have only just discovered it.

December 1, 2016

Dear Sirs and Madams,

I am a physician who was residency trained and Boarded in Family Medicine. I owned and operated a minor emergency for 15 years. During that time I gradually began prescribing fewer and fewer prescription medicines and substituted in natural products and dietary management. I am used to reading on natural plant products in various sources such as The German Commission E. 

After reading the information compiled by the American Kratom Association and the opinions of the scientists who have studied it and the physicians with personal experience with it in their practices, I want kratom to remain unscheduled. It appears to be as safe or safer than acetaminophen and aspirin. In particular, kratom would be my first choice over the use of a narcotic preparation. It can not suppress respiratory status and so is unlikely to cause any permanent damage.

Additional information is needed, such as whether it is in breast milk or if it can be used during pregnancy. Research should be funded with superior grade product. As scientists who have studied it have pointed out, scheduling it will be a hindrance to further study.

While I personally have not taken a prescription medicine in 11 years, if I needed to have a pain medicine available, I would prefer to have unhindered access to kratom in preference to acetaminophen or a narcotic.

Thank you for carefully considering my over 20 years of clinical experience.

Cynthia Jeanne Lee MD

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern;
  My name is Josh, and herbalist and concerned citizen, and I am asking that you please take the time to read my plea to keep kratom legal and available to all. This is every so important.
  This letter comes at the tail end of a public comment period regarding Mitragyna Speciosa, also known as 'Kratom', which has made quite a stir in recent months. Although I mention that only because it took me this long to formulate a response I felt adequate and to the point....and it may still fall short of explaining the importance of this issue to so many.
   Understanding that our country faces an opioid epidemic, one may improperly assume that kratom would add to that issue, considering how it is being portrayed. I would argue that the opposite is true; it has shown to be a safer alternative to help people wean off of them. But let us realize that most of these addictions are not by choice. People are in pain, and seeking relief from their suffering. The over prescription of legal opiates got us into this mess, and kratom is one tool that can help us get out of it. I believe adults should have that decision, not the government. 
   While they have said not enough research has been done to prove it is safe, I would argue that not enough research has been done to show it is dangerous either, and as with all natural products, they should be innocent until proven guilty.
   Addiction is nothing new, and opiate addiction has a long history in the world. We are not the first country to face an epidemic such as this, and surely not the last. Kratom has been used for centuries with no known deaths, regardless of what the media is portraying as true. The cases used to justify this declared 'war on kratom' are misleading, and all of these cases (a mere 15 as stated) can be attributed to a variety of substances in their systems. Kratom by itself has been shown to be safe, and for the millions who use it, very few adverse reactions have occurred; no more than many of the other supplements on the market. 
   As for my personal story; I was a carpenter for several years, until I suffered an extreme sciatic episode where I would not walk for some time. I could barely stand when I did do. As a working man in his 30's, I was devastated. I did not want to take prescription opiates knowing the dangers and addictive potential, so I began taking kratom. It was amazing. Not only did it help remove the pain, but it left me clear headed, and took away the anxiety, so I could still work, and felt functional. It was something I was grateful to have found, then a few years later, we are here in the situation of the federal government trying to interfere with yet another plant that people benefit from. Only this time. It could help us defeat one of the scourges of our society, opiate addiction.
   The claims of no medical use are false, and while I could post the links and details here, I am quite sure that others have inundated the comments with these same statistics. In the end, all we can do is hope that our elected officials will do what is right, and allow people to freely use something they claim helps them. Some of these alkaloids in kratom have already been patented, such as speciofoline, back in the 1960's. They are well known to have therapeutic use, and the research goes way back. Traditionally it was taken by Thai farmers to promote longer work days, and relieve pain. The chances of an overdose as far as we know are none. The history speaks for itself.

    In essence, if it is made illegal, and scheduled, there is little chance it will ever be taken off the list. Very few changes have been made to the schedule list, and it has kept us from researching very useful substances merely out of fear there 'may' be some danger to them.  
   Let us move forward. We are asking that it NOT be placed in ANY of the schedule lists, but is treated like any other supplement, and allowed for people to consume as they please. It is not the kind of plant that attracts people just trying to get 'high', because it does not have that profile. It is very mild, and most youth have no interest in it. However, if it comes to that issue, I think many of us would have no problem making it available for those 18 and older. 
All we are asking is that we have fair and legal access to this amazing plant. Without interference by the federal government, or any entity for that matter.

Thank you for your time,
A concerned citizen-
Joshua Orr

Pharmaceuticals can work as spot fixes, but leave me feeling worse in the long run; they reduce my motivation, make me tired, and have unacceptably negative influences on my ability to think and remember things. That leaves me with a choice between being in pain but functional, or achieving temporary relief at the cost of job performance. This is not an acceptable trade-off. 

Enter Kratom. After doing a lot of reading, looking for some natural supplement that might help, I came across Kratom. The research on it is limited, but its been around long enough to guess at safety for personal use, and didnt appear to have any major negative effects. In short, it sounded like a lot of herbal or alternative medicine. Not a lot of evidence for effectiveness, but nothing too adverse, and plenty of positive  reports. 

That was about 2 years ago. I've been taking Kratom for about 2 years now; about 8 months continuously the first time, followed by a break for about a year, and approaching 10 months this time.

I find that Kratom has a positive effect on my well being. Kratom allows me to function better. Kratom results in less pain and more energy, without forcing me to sacrifice mental clarity or physical ability. While I hesitate to say that its exactly like coffee, I would suggest that its effectiveness, tolerance, usage, and experience quitting is pretty similar. Its kind of a calmer version of the first cup of coffee for the day. I just feel better generally; the pain in my neck fades out of the picture and I can proceed through my day normally. 

If I forget to take it, or skip it that day, I feel about the same as if I skipped my coffee. If I stop taking it, it feels exactly the opposite of quitting coffee; instead of being groggy for a few days, I have trouble sleeping for a few days. 

While I do believe that regulating Kratom in a very general way -- namely with an age limit -- would be wise, any measures beyond that are liable to have a significant negative impact on the well-being of millions of people who use it as an alternative to heavy-duty pharmaceuticals in dealing with mild-to-moderate pain and general malaise.


To state things clearly, though somewhat less personally:

I believe that Kratom should be regulated as a supplement, available to those 21 and up, and with no additional restrictions. 


Kratom has been around for quite some time with limited negative consequences. Millions of Kratom users represent only a small fraction of emergency room visits or poison control calls, and there is an  apparent lack of mortality in sum total when considering incidents involving Kratom alone (non poly-drug). A large body of anecdotal data suggesting that Kratom can, and has, been used to successfully transition off of opiates (either completely, or to less dangerous compounds). There are many current Kratom users, some like myself, who take it in place of powerful pharmaceuticals with severe adverse effect profiles, to generally improve their quality of life. And, there is a great deal of research interest in Kratom currently (at least two papers published in the last 6-8 months, along with a patent based on a compound derived from a modified component of Kratom) that would likely suffer a chilling effect as a result of more stringent regulation.

While Kratom may not be entirely without downsides, it appears it has much more in common with herbal supplements than with pharmaceutical drugs. Things like Coffee, Cats Claw, Ashwaghanda, Bacopa, St. Johns Wort, Kava, various forms of Tea& all have both positive effects, and potential negative effects on the same order of those exhibited by Kratom, and all are expected to be remain legal for the foreseeable future. Please make the correct decision, and group Kratom in with its herbal supplement kin.

Please consider my comments, and the thousands of others made on the topic of Kratom during the review period in making your decisions about the fate of this plant, and, more importantly, about the potential fates of the millions of people who use it in pursuit of improved well-being.

To whom it may concern I would like to leave my comments regarding Kratom and how positively it's affected my life and my ability to function on a day to day basis.
I'm 64 years old, never abused drugs (except for occasional pot smoking in college) of any type and I don't drink alcohol.

daily.  This as well as various triptans ( or ergotamines if I couldn't afford the triptans ) during migraines.

CURRENTLY  I only take 120 mgs of Armour Thyroid and 3-5 gms of Kratom as a powdered leaf.

 I suffer from a chronic illness related to multiple sclerosis. Officially described as HHV6 of the CNS. Not only is the virus active but it's caused an autoimmune response. I've had it since 2003 and it is both painful and debilitating and has caused me great anguish.
I've been treated with Valcyte to reduce the viral load and Rituxan to mediate the autoimmune response. My current physician is Andreas Kogelnik, MD and infectious disease specialist who practices in Mountain View California.

 Because of my illness I have had to take pain relieving drugs for many years and struggle with the usual host of symptoms associated with their use.
 At one point I was taking OxyContin 10mg 2xd, but because of the need to increase the dose and how incredibly addictive I'd heard the drug was I discontinued its use. To replace it,  are used tramadol and gabapentin along with various other over-the-counter analgesics such as ibuprofen, naproxen sodium and others. For the migraines are associated with my disease, I used a variety of triptans and ergot based drugs. Also many preventative drugs, calcium channel blockers, Topamax etc were tried. Along with Excedrin which is oddly the one drug that's proved somewhat effective in aborting the migraine after onset.
All the drugs that I used were prescribed by various neurologists and rheumatologists etc, and I used them according to directions and never abused them.
 With constant pain from the disease as well as up to 15 migraines a month, the drugs barely kept me functioning at a very minimal level.
One of my physicians, the now deceased  Harvey Caplan, M.D., suggested that I try various herbal drugs since the pharmaceutical drugs I was using we're not working very well.
I tried various marijuana preparations and unfortunately they made my migraines worse. Then a very good friend ( a Rheumatiod arthritis sufferer) suggested Kratom. After several months I purchased some and tried it another several months later.
I'll try to shorten this as much as I can but the bottom line was until I found kratom my life was a living hell. My migraines are currently down to about 3 a month. Although I know that the statement from one person can be viewed as anecdotal, I have heard similar stories from many people. My only regret is that it took me so long to find something that has helped me as much as Kratom leaves have.
Please enter my statement into your record and feel free to contact me at any time regarding my experience with Kratom.

Barbara Brodsky

documents.commentText:
The scheduling of drugs in intended to restrict only those drugs which are actively identified as purely harmful with no redeeming medicinal properties. In the case of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, components of kratom, the benefits are discernable and obvious from examination of its medical effects among current domestic users as well as users abroad. As other countries have already acknowledged its beneficial properties and allow the usage of kratom, it is reasonable and appropriate to allow US citizens access to the benefits of it.

While it is possible to abuse almost any substance, that only argues for rational use, but not a complete ban. Even caffeine in coffee has hospitalized individuals who have gone to extremes with it, yet coffee remains a favorite among Americans and people the world over.

That kratom has not resulted in significant problems and has provided  significant medical benefit, specifically managing pain and assisting in withdrawal from opioids (opioid addiction being a significant problem in the US requiring more solutions, not fewer) indicates that the continued availability of kratom  be maintained.

Please do not criminalize components of a natural herb that can continue to be of such great benefit to many, many Americans dealing with chronic pain or opioid withdrawal.

Further, I recommend a review of the current scheduling of other materials to determine of there is actually reason to maintain them under their current schedules or if their scheduling be relaxed and that this review be performed periodically on all currently scheduled materials to be sure that all current medical information be applied in making medically valuable materials available to American patients for treating their medical conditions.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I am a business owner who has sold Kratom over the past five years to our customers in the San Francisco area. During these five years, I have had a few experiences that I would like to share here and which seem pertinent to this inquiry that the DEA is performing (for which I am very appreciative.)
Firstly, I would like to speak on behalf of the hundreds of individuals who we have had the pleasure of serving (we offer and sell many other herbs in addition to Kratom, but of course for this issue I'm referring to Kratom.) The benefits that have been reported from our customers have been profound and varied - such as reduced dependence on dangerous and addictive opiate pain drugs, effective pain relief without addiction, reduced use of (again addictive and dangerous) alcohol and other recreational drugs, and relief from debilitating symptoms of anxiety and depression. I can not overstate the joy and relief that has been expressed to us through the years as people have discovered the ways that Kratom has benefitted their life. 
Secondly, closer to home, I have seen firsthand the great benefit that Kratom has brought into my wife's life for relieving extremely painful period cramps. Far beyond the relief found from any OTC pain reliever, Kratom has allowed her to be productive and find peace on days which would otherwise be lost to her cramps. 
Lastly, on a personal level, I have found Kratom incredibly helpful during a bout with an ear infection which was extremely painful and during a couple moderate injuries that I sustained while rock climbing. Powerfully effective with NO side effects and no feeling of dependency afterward. I feel like this point is important to dwell on: there have been times when I have used Kratom daily for months at a time - and after these times I was able to stop using Kratom without any trouble. (I have had more trouble stopping coffee at times in the past!) 

I think that there's an important distinction around the addiction issue that I haven't seen expressed often (if ever). The people I have seen struggle with stopping Kratom were using it to wean off of opiates. We would never suggest that someone do this, but I do feel that Kratom, which has an incredible safety profile, is a far better option than the opiate family which kills ~40,000 American individuals per year! From my vantage point of having seen many hundreds of people try Kratom for various reasons,the only addiction that I've seen is addiction based on months or years of opiate use - and after using Kratom for weeks or months, the addiction has reduced but remains present to a more manageable extent. Of course addiction is often a multifaceted issue which requires attention beyond the physical addiction, but offering people a safe alternative from deadly substances while a person finds their way through the challenging waters of addiction seems like a great idea. 

From my years of experience - both personal and related from our many customers - the question of efficacy is certain. This is an amazing plant from God's green earth which has the potential to bring relief for many  people on many fronts. 
Regarding the issue of safety, I understand that there have been a number of people who have used Kratom and died. I also understand from reading about these cases that most deaths involved other substances, so to call Kratom the cause is not necessarily accurate. This question could certainly use more inquiry, but deeming it a threat to humanity, when it has already helped so many individuals escape the clutches of a truly deadly class of chemicals is, I think, doing far more harm than good (i hope the point of harm versus benefit will be thoroughly examined in this process!)
And regarding the addiction question, I think it's more complex than how it's often looked at. By far most people who have used Kratom as non opiate-users have found it to be nonaddictive or on par with coffee. If someone is using it to wean off of opiates, it's not the Kratom which has caused the addiction. Kratom has just helped the individual find safer ground on which the healing can begin. 

I hope that this comment process will open the eyes and minds of the honorable DEA administrator to the many reasons why Kratom should remain available to the public for the foreseeable future. The opitae epidemic needs this, and the responsible public is benefitting greatly from this herb. 
Many thanks.

To whom it may concern, 

I am a board-certified Pain Management specialist. Over the last 5 years, I have witnessed an increasing number of patients successfully using Kratom to alleviate a variety of symptoms, with no documented negative events. Therefore, I am adamantly against the banning of Kratom. Most of these patients turned to Kratom have chronic pain, are over the age of 50, and have been on opiod therapy for 10+ years. 

Since Kratom has not been approved for consumption by the FDA, I cannot specifically recommend my patients use it for it's medicinal properties, however I sincerely wish that I COULD recommend this supplement due to the reasons I will outline below.

My patients are very open with me about their medications, including herbal supplements. In the past 5 years, I have witnessed over 50 of my patients successfully substitute Kratom to alleviate their chronic pain in lieu of narcotics. Every time they come to the clinic for follow-up and I review their blood panels, I have noticed a marked improvement in their lab values (such as liver transaminases). However, most importantly, the improvement I have seen in their QUALITY OF LIFE, has been nothing short of miraculous. 

Patients who were previously disabled by their chronic pain and side effects of narcotic therapies, have been much more active, many have been able to return to work, and often describe Kratom as a "life-saver". When the DEA announced a sudden ban on Kratom and its alkaloids, the concern and panic our clinic received from patients was extremely concerning. One patient actually stated, "If this ban happens we are moving to Canada", because she refused to resume taking narcotics for her chronic back pain.

As a physician, I believe that the DEA's motion to ban Kratom is reckless, irresponsible, and not based on scientific facts. I have yet to see a patient who was negatively impacted by Kratom in any way, and the published articles I have read support this. Furthermore, In speaking with my colleagues at the hospital, we have yet to see a single patient present with a Kratom "overdose", "addiction", or negative lab values. Upon further research, I have come to understand that Kratom has a unique "ceiling effect", which prevents users from achieving any sort of euphoric "high" that is present with the majority of the prescription pain medications available for severe chronic pain. Patients who used Kratom simply reported alleviation of their chronic pain, along with some mild anti-depressive/anxiolytic benefits. Additionally, patients reported increased energy levels that had plummeted since beginning narcotic pain management.

The botanical relative of Kratom, the coffee plant, is a great example what happens if a patient attempts to somehow abuse Kratom. I am actually more concerned about patients abusing coffee and caffeine than a patient abusing Kratom . If a patient drinks 10 espresso shots, they will become nauseated and experience GI distress...which is exactly what happens with Kratom. However if a patient were to accidentally ingest too much Kratom, they are less likely to have the severe cardiac arrhythmias that occur with a caffeine overdose. In this way, I feel that a ban on Kratom would be analagous to the DEA attempting to ban caffeine. In our clinic, we have not seen any patients complain of "Kratom withdrawal symptoms/addiction". 

Quality of life for my patients is of utmost importance to me, and the simple fact is, every patient we have seen in clinic who has discontinued narcotic therapy in lieu of Kratom supplementation has had a *significant* improvement in their quality of life. These patients vehemently do NOT want to return to narcotic therapy. 

If the DEA chooses to ban Kratom, I have no doubt there will be a marked increase in the number of narcotic-related morbidities and deaths. 

Furthermore, when the DEA attempted to swiftly ban Kratom in September, I came to understand more about the Kratom community. These users are not teens chasing a "legal high". From what we have seen in clinic and in the published studies, there is no physiological euphoric "high" seen with Kratom. The majority of the community is comprised of parents, grandparents, and responsible members of society who are simply trying to manage their chronic pain with a natural remedy and regain control of their lives after years of narcotic pain management. I am far more concerned about my patients who are on narcotic medications than patients who decided to help alleviate their chronic pain with Kratom. A review of the published articles will reveal that there have been 0 deaths or negative outcomes associated with Kratom use. 

In summary, I sincerely urge the DEA to make the responsible and informed decision to allow Kratom to remain legal so that we can keep the number of deaths/morbidities caused by narcotics as low as possible.

Thank you for receiving our comments. This really seems to be a first step towards a better relationship between "we the people" and the DEA. It always seems unfortunate when the general population begins to distrust and hate a government agency that is not a monolith and is itself not relegated to a singular dogmatic perspective on any given subject. 

I am an ex-heroin addict. Many people think that opiate addicts are just weak and/or stupid people but that is not the case. I was a model student and son and I simply was trying to find a way to cope with an emotional response to sexual abuse in my childhood (that is the case with many addicts). 

I heard about Kratom years ago when a friend of mine told me it helped him ease withdrawal symptoms. Since then, I have used it to get clean over 10 times. Frankly, the looming fear of the pain of withdrawal makes it terrifying for me to even think about getting off of opiates without it. Unlike opiates, kratom has never caused withdrawal symptoms for me (other than a runny nose). I have never gotten "high" on kratom, it simply eased withdrawal symptoms. I'm sure if you took enough it would have a stronger effect but it never had any abuse potential for me nor have I ever heard of someone becoming addicted to kratom in the same way that someone becomes addicted to opiates. 

Any drug, including caffeine, has some potential for abuse but if the benefits of the drug outweigh the detriments, it should not be illegal. This is a boon for mankind. Especially with the opiate epidemic. It keeps me going to work, reading, writing and being generally productive. It keeps us on the straight and narrow and allows us to become functioning members of society again. 

Please reconsider making kratom illegal. It is not going to be as easy for people to fight withdrawal; and by extension, opiate addiction, if it simply becomes a prescription medication. Whenever an opioid is synthesized by pharmaceutical companies, they isolate the single molecule that has an opioid-like effect. The net result is that it becomes more addictive and more potent. I would guess that it is the other alkaloids in the mitragyna speciosa plant that produce the overall effect of kratom (that is, an effect which eases withdrawal without getting the user high and thus causing them to fall into yet another cycle of addiction). The overall response to kratom legality on a state by state basis should give you some direction as to whether or not kratom should be added to the controlled substances list. By and large, local politicians have seen the positive role it has played in their communities.

documents.commentText: Placing Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine Into Schedule I will inhibit academic research into its clinical toxicity and potential therapeutic use as a medication for analgesia or even opiate detoxification.  These two extremes in its potential therapeutic application deserve examination in view of the current opiate epidemic and need for therapeutic alternatives.  These compounds are not likely to be examined by pharmaceutical companies for any therapeutic use due to their inability to be patent protected.  However, academic examination through NIH or other funding mechanisms could provide valuable information, and getting FDA approval for human or even animal studies with Schedule 1 substances is very difficult, even when the compounds themselves can be relatively easily obtained for such testing.  If scheduling appears necessary for other reasons, then I suggest that a lower category such as schedule 3 be considered.  These substances do not appear to be widely abused in the USA in my experience in the emergency departments of our hospitals in Houston or in the patients coming to our addictions treatment programs.  Opiate addicted patients are using Kratom to relieve opiate withdrawal symptoms, but do not describe any euphoria that it produces.  These observations need replication in controlled human laboratory studies with both opiate abusers and non-abusers.  Doing such studies with a schedule 1 substance will be extremely difficult and obtaining funding for such studies will pose further difficulties or impossibilities because of the schedule 1 categorization.  We need more scientific information from human studies, and this scheduling to schedule 1 will prevent such human studies.  Thomas Kosten MD, Professor of Psychiatry and Pharmacology, Past Presidents, American Academy of Addiction Psychiatry and College on Problems of Drug Dependence

I'm a college professor that teaches in the health discipline.  Around 2005, I was in a motorcycle accident that did some damage to my AC joint.  It's an injury that is slow to heal, I had some degree of pain or discomfort for over a year.  During this time, I became addicted to the prescribed pain medication.  Once the pain was gone, I fell into a life-consuming addiction.  I drove myself into debt, ruined my credit and personal relationships - sadly, it's not a unique story.  I pulled myself out of this cycle by using Kratom as a substitute.  I stopped using opioids in 2012, went back to university, got an advanced degree, and now I contribute by teaching biological sciences.  
I feel as if there is a great deal of misinformation about kratom's effects on the user, particularly the 'high'.  I find it to be just ever-so-slightly more profound than a cup of coffee.  It is nowhere close to the high experienced with alcohol or marijuana (a drug that looks as if it may be legalized in the near future), and miles from the all-encompassing effects of an actual opioid.  To compare to another category of drug, stimulants, Kratom is to opioids as coffee is to methamphetamines.  There is a certain pleasant lift to Kratom, but it doesn't disorient, impair coordination or destroy judgement.  What it does is lightly tickle the opioid receptors to completely eliminate craving.  I tried unsuccessfully for several years to get myself out of my cycle of addiction and the part that always led to relapse was the craving and depression experienced daily.  I couldn't concentrate on anything, my thoughts were consumed with drug fantasies.  There is an initial temptation for the novice user, something along the lines of "I wonder if I triple my intake, will I feel that old overwhelming high?"   One quickly learns that the answer is a resounding "no". What the user gets by following through with this train of thought is, put simply, a headache that lasts for about 2 hours. Drug abusive behavior is self defeating and self limiting.  To go back to the coffee analogy, there is a certain point where caffeine over consumption becomes unpleasant, and that point is well before it becomes life threatening. Kratom is similar in that regard. 
It is for this reason that I believe scheduling Kratom is an overreaction.  Kratom's effects are mild and abusive behavior is self limiting.  It has dramatically improved my outcome and outlook as it has for many others. I thank you for taking the time to read my opinion.

I was actually separated from service early due to a Medical Board that found me unable to continue serving with these injuries.  I finished school and got a desk job after service, and in late 2009, I continued treatment for my ailments through both the VA and through private physician. There were varying degrees of success with each course of treatment, but as I continued with all of my treatments, they all became less and less effective, and the pain grew to unbearable levels.  I always took the prescribed amount of medication, but every month, the dosage and number of pills would increase as they seemed to lose their effectiveness.  Then, couple that with the awful side effects, the constant lethargy, where my only options seemed to be either (1) be miserable and in agony, or (2) be in slightly less pain, but perpetually exhausted. There were many sleepless, emotional nights where I would break down and wonder if every day would be like this for the rest of my life.  Would I have to call out of work a few times a month if I couldn't bear to move out of bed?  If I was married, or had children: How could I manage an active lifestyle with them without dragging them through this?  From experience, I know how frustrating and powerless it is to watch your loved ones suffer, and I never wanted to put anyone in the position where they would have to worry about me like that.
