December 1, 2016 


To Whom It May Concern, In Reference To Docket No. DEA-442W: 


As an American citizen, I completely object to the proposed emergency scheduling of Kratom into a schedule 1 drug. 


Mitragyna Speciosa, commonly known as Kratom, is a plant in the coffee family that is native to Southeast Asia and has been an integral part of some cultures for centuries. Although relatively unheard of in our American society, this herbal plant is no more dangerous than one's morning cup of coffee or tea. 


In a time of rampant prescription drug abuse, it stands to reason that taking this plant and subjecting it to the harshest scheduling available would only cause more problems. Statistically, opioids have proven to be a far more dangerous threat to public safety and health, causing new addictions and fatal overdoses daily. 


To classify, and thereby ban Kratom, as a schedule 1 drug, is a move which is unprecedented and uncalled for. The scheduling of Kratom into a class 1 drug would not only severely limit any future research on this beneficial plant, but would also turn functioning, productive members of our society into criminals overnight. Just as we would not ban or regulate one's daily coffee intake, so too should we not inflict such unreasonable restrictions on the Kratom plant.


It is the DEA's responsibility to act in the best interest of the American public, however to ban a substance which has gotten significantly less calls to Poison Control than everyday laundry detergent pods would be to jump to damaging conclusions. Like any substance, the unbiased studying of the Kratom plant may help us to better understand its effects during use. However, a schedule 1 classification would lead to a severe restriction on such research and ultimately cripple the possibilities that this plant could offer to many suffering Americans. Many polls suggest that the average Kratom user is none other than your average, productive member of the Baby Boomer generation, rather than someone simply seeking a recreational high. 


Personally, I have witnessed the numerous benefits that can be experienced from the responsible consumption of the Kratom plant. After a surgical malpractice which left a hole in his rib cage, my husband was diagnosed with Post Thoracotomy Pain Syndrome (PTPS). PTPS is a rare condition which leaves the sufferer struggling with debilitating chronic pain, and oftentimes, missing rib cage bones. Due to this, my husband is partially disabled and in severe chronic pain everyday. Traditional modern medicine prescribes my husband intense opioids to treat and manage the pain and nerve damage. However, these opioids come with their own set of side effects, many of which only add to his daily struggle. His prescribed use of opioids left him with no appetite, constipation, and dulled senses among other debilitating side effects.


After discovering Kratom, my husband was able to buy it legally over the counter from a reputable source. He was not subjected to the dangerous underground market, but was treated like a normal human being looking for natural pain relief. In the two years since, I have watched how the incorporation of Kratom into a holistic lifestyle has significantly helped his quality of life. Not only was my husband able to wean himself off of the highly addictive opioids, but he also functions better on a daily basis due to his consumption of Kratom. When he uses Kratom as part of his holistic pain management, he is able to have substantial pain relief, eat regularly, and in general, function better. Through the use of Kratom, my husband has been able to not only actually function in his daily life but also be a better father when he otherwise would be in too much pain to even get out of bed. 


To ban Kratom would not only negatively affect my husband but would damage our entire family, leaving my newborn daughter without the dad she could otherwise have. Without Kratom, my husband would suffer from disabling chronic pain too much to be an active part in her life and she would be unnecessarily robbed of the possibilities of such an important relationship. Like so many other children, the Kratom plant plays a significant role in the quality of life of parents across the nation which results in a positive effect for our daughter among others.  


In conclusion, America is the land of the free and to take away our God given right to consume an herbal plant without harm to others is to disgrace all that we have fought for. Although the DEA considers anecdotal evidence to be subjective at best, the witness of such experiences should in and of itself prove that in the best interest of the American population the DEA would be seriously remiss to inflict an unsubstantiated emergency scheduling of the herbal substance commonly known as Kratom.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should not place kratom on Schedule I. 

First, there is no scientific evidence demonstrating that kratom has high abuse liability without any medical benefit, which are among the criteria for Schedule I drugs. In fact, there is very little evidence for or against the use of kratom at all. For example, a PubMed search from 11/30/16 returns only 86 results for the term kratom, and only 131 for the term mitragynine. This is hardly a large enough body of empirical work on which to base decisions about banning kratom. (For comparison, a PubMed search for alcohol returns over 855,000 unique articles.)

This empirical literature is mixed. While there have been reports of toxicity related to kratom use,1 a review of the literature reveals that these appear to be a uniquely Western phenomenon, and in these cases, kratom was largely being used with other drugs.2 In Southeast Asia, where kratom originates and has been used for centuries, death has not been known to result from kratom use.2 Kratom has been found to have potential for both therapy and abuse.3,4 More research is desperately needed on kratom and its constituents,2,5 and placing kratom in Schedule I would effectively prohibit this research. 

This research would be especially timely, as America is in the midst of an opioid epidemic. Overdose rates are skyrocketing, and I see this borne out in epidemiological studies as well as in the loss of my loved ones. We need every tool we can get to fight the devastation caused by opioid addiction. Importantly, kratom has been identified as a potential tool for helping people who suffer from addiction: it can act as an analgesic itself, and users report that it is a great help in the painful process of opioid withdrawal.6 This can help people detoxify from opioids, which is one of the major barriers to entering recovery. I argue that we should be promoting research into any avenue that can help end the opioid epidemic. Research in this area is limited, and scheduling kratom would further limit this research.

I do not support the scheduling of kratom, or its constituent chemicals, at this time. This would not be an evidence-based decision, as there is too little evidence to draw from. A Schedule I placement would further limit empirical research. While waiting for this research, people suffering from chronic pain and addiction are already using kratom to improve their health and functioning. Scheduling kratom at this time is simply not sensible for patients and scientists, nor a good use of the DEAs resources. 

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on this proposed rule. 


References
1. Anwar M, Law R, Schier J. Notes from the field: Kratom (mitragyna speciosa) exposures reported to poison centers - United States, 2010-2015. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2016;65(29):748-749. doi: 10.15585/mmwr.mm6529a4.
2. Singh D, Narayanan S, Vicknasingam B. Traditional and non-traditional uses of mitragynine (kratom): A survey of the literature. Brain Res Bull. 2016;126(Pt 1):41-46. doi: S0361-9230(16)30101-0.
3. Hassan Z, Muzaimi M, Navaratnam V, et al. From kratom to mitragynine and its derivatives: Physiological and behavioural effects related to use, abuse, and addiction. Neurosci Biobehav Rev. 2013;37(2):138-151. doi: 10.1016/j.neubiorev.2012.11.012.
4. Prozialeck WC. Update on the pharmacology and legal status of kratom. J Am Osteopath Assoc. 2016;116(12):802-809. doi: 10.7556/jaoa.2016.156].
5. Ward J, Rosenbaum C, Hernon C, McCurdy CR, Boyer EW. Herbal medicines for the management of opioid addiction: Safe and effective alternatives to conventional pharmacotherapy? CNS Drugs. 2011;25(12):999-1007. doi: 10.2165/11596830-000000000-00000.
6. Swogger MT, Hart E, Erowid F, et al. Experiences of kratom users: A qualitative analysis. J Psychoactive Drugs. 2015;47(5):360-367. doi: 10.1080/02791072.2015.1096434.
